natural problem: An o-Pod MP3 player stores and plays entire songs. Celeste has 10 songs stored on her o-Pod. The time length of each song is different. When the songs are ordered by length, the shortest song is only 30 seconds long and each subsequent song is 30 seconds longer than the previous song. Her favorite song is 3 minutes, 30 seconds long. The o-Pod will play all the songs in random order before repeating any song. What is the probability that she hears the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds of music - there are no pauses between songs - without hearing every second of her favorite song? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: We will calculate the probability of her hearing every second of her favorite song and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $10!$ ways in which the 10 songs can be ordered.

If her favorite song is the first song, she obviously hears the whole thing, and then there are $9!$ ways to order the other songs. If the first song is the 30 second song, then she will hear the entirety of her favorite song if and only if it is played as the second song, after which there are $8!$ ways to order the other songs.

Finally, if the first song is the 1 minute song, she will hear her favorite song if and only if it is played as the second song, after which there are $8!$ ways to order the other songs. If the first song is longer than a minute, or if two songs are played before her first song, she won't have time to hear all of her favorite song in the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds.

So out of the $10!$ ways of ordering the 10 songs, there are $9! + 8! + 8!$ ways that result in her hearing the full song for a probability of $\dfrac{9!+8!+8!}{10!}=\dfrac{8!}{8!}\cdot\dfrac{9+1+1}{10\cdot9}=\dfrac{11}{90}$.
But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{11}{90}=\boxed{\dfrac{79}{90}}$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real and songs_lengths :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "songs_lengths 1 = 30"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {1..9} \<longrightarrow> songs_lengths (n+1) = songs_lengths n + 30"
and h2 : "songs_lengths 7 = 210"
and h3 : "(\<forall> n \<in> {1..10}. songs_lengths n \<ge> 30)"
and h4 : "p = (\<lambda> (success_cases :: nat) (total_cases :: nat). real success_cases / real total_cases) (10 * 9)"
shows  "p = 79 / 90"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An o-Pod MP3 player stores and plays entire songs. Celeste has 10 songs stored on her o-Pod. The time length of each song is different. What is the probability that she hears the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds of music - there are no pauses between songs - without hearing every second of her favorite song? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{79}{90}
 ### Proof
 We will calculate the probability of her hearing every second of her favorite song and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $10!$ ways in which the 10 songs can be ordered.
 If her favorite song is the first song, she obviously hears the whole thing, and then there are $9!$ ways to order the other songs. If the first song is the 30 second song, then she will hear the entirety of her favorite song if and only if it is played as the second song, after which there are $8!$ ways to order the other songs.
 Finally, if the first song is the 1 minute song, she will hear her favorite song if and only if it is played as the second song, after which there are $8!$ ways to order the other songs.  But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{11}{90}=\boxed{\dfrac{79}{90}}$
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real and songs_lengths :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "songs_lengths 1 = 30"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {1..9} \<longrightarrow> songs_lengths (n+1) = songs_lengths n + 30"
and h2 : "songs_lengths 7 = 210"
and h3 : "(\<forall> n \<in> {1..10}. songs_lengths n \<ge> 30)"
and h4 : "p = (\<lambda> (success_cases :: nat) (total_cases :: nat). real success_cases / real total_cases) (10 * 9)"
shows  "p = 79 / 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 10 songs on a playlist, and the length of each song increases by 30 seconds from the previous song. The first song lasts for 30 seconds, and the seventh song lasts for 210 seconds. All the songs last at least 30 seconds. Find the probability that a randomly chosen pair of songs has a total length less than or equal to 10 minutes (i.e., 600 seconds). The final answer is $\frac{79}{90}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_songs :: real
assumes h0 : "total_songs = 10"
and h1 : "shortest_song_length = 30"
and h2 : "favorite_song_length = 210"
and h3 : "total_play_time = 270"
and h4 : "\<forall>n \<in> {1..9}. (\<forall> song_length. (song_length n) = (shortest_song_length + 30 * n))"
and h5 : "prob_not_hearing_favorite = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..9}. (1/total_songs) * (1 - (1/(total_songs - 1))) ^ i)"
shows  "prob_not_hearing_favorite = 79/90"

theorem
fixes total_songs :: real
assumes h0 : "total_songs = 10"
and h1 : "shortest_song_length = 30"
and h2 : "favorite_song_length = 210"
and h3 : "total_play_time = 270"
and h4 : "\<forall>n \<in> {1..9}. (\<forall> song_length. (song_length n) = (shortest_song_length + 30 * n))"
and h5 : "prob_not_hearing_favorite = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..9}. (1/total_songs) * (1 - (1/(total_songs - 1))) ^ i)"
shows  "prob_not_hearing_favorite = 79/90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: You have a playlist with 10 songs. The shortest song is 30 seconds long, and your favorite song is 210 seconds long. The total playtime of all songs is 270 seconds. Each of the other 9 songs is 30 seconds longer than the previous song. What is the probability that you won't hear your favorite song if you listen to the playlist for a random amount of time? The final answer is $\frac{79}{90}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes songs :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and t_favorite :: nat
and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "songs 1 = 30"
and h1 : "\<forall>n \<in> {2..10}. songs n = songs (n - 1) + 30"
and h2 : "t_favorite = 210"
and h3 : "\<forall>n \<in> {1..10}. P n = 1 / 10"
and h4 : "no_repeats songs"
shows  "P (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..4}. songs n) = 79 / 90"
a_2.formal solution:

theorem
fixes songs :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and t_favorite :: nat
and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "songs 1 = 30"
and h1 : "\<forall>n \<in> {2..10}. songs n = songs (n - 1) + 30"
and h2 : "t_favorite = 210"
and h3 : "\<forall>n \<in> {1..10}. P n = 1 / 10"
and h4 : "no_repeats songs"
shows  "P (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..4}. songs n) = 79 / 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 10 songs in a playlist. The first song has a duration of 30 seconds, and the duration of each subsequent song is 30 seconds longer than the previous one. If your favorite song is the one with a total duration of 210 seconds and the probability of each song being played is equal (1/10), what is the probability that your favorite song will be played by the time the first 4 songs have been played, considering there are no repeats? The final answer is 79/90.

theorem
fixes prob :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "prob = (79 / 90)"
shows  "prob = (probability of hearing the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds of music without hearing every second of her favorite song)"

a_3.informal problem: What is the probability of hearing the first 4 minutes and 30 seconds of music without hearing every second of her favorite song? The final answer is $\frac{79}{90}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (79 / 90)"
shows  "p = (prob_of_not_hearing_every_second_of_favorite_song 10 30 210 270)"

a_4.informal problem: Determine the probability of not hearing every second of a favorite song when played 10 times, if the song is 30 seconds long and the listening session lasts 210 to 270 seconds. The final answer is $\frac{79}{90}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (79 / 90 :: real)"
shows  "p = (card {seq | seq \<in> {1..10} \<rightarrow> {1..10} \<and> inj_on seq {1..10} \<and> (\<exists> n \<in> {1..9}. seq n = 4 \<and> seq (n+1) \<noteq> 5)}) / fact 10"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An o-Pod MP3 player stores and plays entire songs. Celeste has 10 songs stored on her o-Pod. The time length of each song is different. When the songs are ordered by length, the shortest song is only 30 seconds long and each subsequent song is 30 seconds longer than the previous song. Her favorite song is 3 minutes, 30 seconds long. The o-Pod will play all the songs in random order before repeating any song. What is the probability that she hears the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds of music - there are no pauses between songs - without hearing every second of her favorite song? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{79}{90}
 ### Proof
 We will calculate the probability of her hearing every second of her favorite song and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $10!$ ways in which the 10 songs can be ordered.
 If her favorite song is the first song, she obviously hears the whole thing, and then there are $9!$ ways to order the other songs. If the first song is the 30 second song, then she will hear the entirety of her favorite song if and only if it is played as the second song, after which there are $8!$ ways to order the other songs.
 Finally, if the first song is the 1 minute song, she will hear her favorite song if and only if it is played as the second song, after which there are $8!$ ways to order the other songs. If the first song is longer than a minute, or if two songs are played before her first song, she won't have time to hear all of her favorite song in the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds.
 So out of the $10!$ ways of ordering the 10 songs, there are $9! + 8! + 8!$ ways that result in her hearing the full song for a probability of $\dfrac{9!+8!+8!}{10!}=\dfrac{8!}{8!}\cdot\dfrac{9+1+1}{10\cdot9}=\dfrac{11}{90}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{11}{90}=\boxed{\dfrac{79}{90}}$
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (79 / 90 :: real)"
shows  "p = (card {seq | seq \<in> {1..10} \<rightarrow> {1..10} \<and> inj_on seq {1..10} \<and> (\<exists> n \<in> {1..9}. seq n = 4 \<and> seq (n+1) \<noteq> 5)}) / fact 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a permutation of the numbers 1 to 10, what is the probability that 4 is immediately followed by a number other than 5? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{79}{90}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes songs :: "nat list" and favorite_song :: nat
assumes h0 : "length songs = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> i < 9. songs ! i + 30 = songs ! (i+1)"
and h2 : "songs ! 0 = 30"
and h3 : "favorite_song = 210"
and h4 : "list_all (\<lambda> x. x \<noteq> favorite_song) songs"
and h5 : "\<forall> p \<in> set (permutations songs). 270 \<notin> set (map (\<lambda> x. sum_list (take x p)) [1..<length p]))"
shows  "79 / 90 = (\<Sum>p\<in>set (permutations songs). if 270 \<in> set (map (\<lambda> x. sum_list (take x p)) [1..<length p]) then 0 else 1) / fact 10"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An o-Pod MP3 player stores and plays entire songs. Celeste has 10 songs stored on her o-Pod. The time length of each song is different.  ### Proof

 If her favorite song is the first song, she obviously hears the whole thing, and then there are $9!$ ways to order the other songs. If the first song is longer than a minute, or if two songs are played before her first song, she won't have time to hear all of her favorite song in the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds.
 So out of the $10!$ ways of ordering the 10 songs, there are $9! + 8! + 8!$ ways that result in her hearing the full song for a probability of $\dfrac{9!+8!+8!}{10!}=\dfrac{8!}{8!}\cdot\dfrac{9+1+1}{10\cdot9}=\dfrac{11}{90}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{11}{90}=\boxed{\dfrac{79}{90}}$
 *)

theorem
fixes songs :: "nat list" and favorite_song :: nat
assumes h0 : "length songs = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> i < 9. songs ! i + 30 = songs ! (i+1)"
and h2 : "songs ! 0 = 30"
and h3 : "favorite_song = 210"
and h4 : "list_all (\<lambda> x. x \<noteq> favorite_song) songs"
and h5 : "\<forall> p \<in> set (permutations songs). 270 \<notin> set (map (\<lambda> x. sum_list (take x p)) [1..<length p]))"
shows  "79 / 90 = (\<Sum>p\<in>set (permutations songs). if 270 \<in> set (map (\<lambda> x. sum_list (take x p)) [1..<length p]) then 0 else 1) / fact 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: You have a playlist of 10 songs with the lengths of each song increasing by 30 seconds from the first song. The first song is 30 seconds long and your favorite song is 210 seconds long. Your favorite song is not in the playlist. Calculate the probability that the total playing time of any subset of the playlist is not 270 seconds when the songs are played in any order. The final answer is $\frac{79}{90}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 < p \<and> p \<le> 1"
and h1 : "p = 79 / 90"
shows  "p = probability that Celeste hears the first 4 minutes 30 seconds of music without hearing every second of her favorite song"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{11}{90}=\boxed{\dfrac{79}{90}}$
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 < p \<and> p \<le> 1"
and h1 : "p = 79 / 90"
shows  "p = probability that Celeste hears the first 4 minutes 30 seconds of music without hearing every second of her favorite song"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: What is the probability that Celeste hears the first 4 minutes and 30 seconds of music without hearing every second of her favorite song, given that the probability is between 0 and 1? The final answer is $\frac{79}{90}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_favSong :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P_favSong = 3 * 60 + 30"
and h1 : "P_favSong \<le> 4 * 60 + 30"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. i < 10 \<and> i \<noteq> 3 \<longrightarrow> P_favSong < i * 30"
and h3 : "\<forall>i. i < 10 \<and> i \<noteq> 3 \<longrightarrow> P_favSong + 30 > i * 30"
shows  "P (Celeste does not hear every second of her favorite song in the first 4 * 60 + 30 seconds) = 79 / 90"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An o-Pod MP3 player stores and plays entire songs. Celeste has 10 songs stored on her o-Pod. The time length of each song is different. What is the probability that she hears the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds of music - there are no pauses between songs - without hearing every second of her favorite song? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{79}{90}
 ### Proof
 We will calculate the probability of her hearing every second of her favorite song and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $10!$ ways in which the 10 songs can be ordered.
 If her favorite song is the first song, she obviously hears the whole thing, and then there are $9!$ ways to order the other songs. If the first song is the 30 second song, then she will hear the entirety of her favorite song if and only if it is played as the second song, after which there are $8!$ ways to order the other songs.
 Finally, if the first song is the 1 minute song, she will hear her favorite song if and only if it is played as the second song, after which there are $8!$ ways to order the other songs. If the first song is longer than a minute, or if two songs are played before her first song, she won't have time to hear all of her favorite song in the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds.
 So out of the $10!$ ways of ordering the 10 songs, there are $9! + 8! + 8!$ ways that result in her hearing the full song for a probability of $\dfrac{9!+8!+8!}{10!}=\dfrac{8!}{8!}\cdot\dfrac{9+1+1}{10\cdot9}=\dfrac{11}{90}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{11}{90}=\boxed{\dfrac{79}{90}}$
 *)

theorem
fixes P_favSong :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P_favSong = 3 * 60 + 30"
and h1 : "P_favSong \<le> 4 * 60 + 30"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. i < 10 \<and> i \<noteq> 3 \<longrightarrow> P_favSong < i * 30"
and h3 : "\<forall>i. i < 10 \<and> i \<noteq> 3 \<longrightarrow> P_favSong + 30 > i * 30"
shows  "P (Celeste does not hear every second of her favorite song in the first 4 * 60 + 30 seconds) = 79 / 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Celeste's favorite song has a length of 3 minutes and 30 seconds. She starts listening to music for 4 minutes and 30 seconds. What is the probability that Celeste does not hear every second of her favorite song in the first 4 minutes and 30 seconds, if there are 10 equally likely intervals, each 30 seconds long, at which her favorite song could start playing, but it cannot start at the 3rd interval? The final answer is $\frac{79}{90}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (79 / 90)"
shows  "p = (card {L. \<exists> S1 S2 S3 S4 S5 S6 S7 S8 S9 S10. 
                 L = [S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, S7, S8, S9, S10] \<and>
                 (\<forall> S. S \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> (S = 30 \<or> S = 60 \<or> S = 90 \<or> S = 120 \<or> S = 150 \<or> S = 180 \<or> S = 210)) \<and>
                 (\<forall> S1 S2. S1 \<noteq> S2 \<longrightarrow> S1 \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> S2 \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> S1 \<noteq> S2) \<and>
                 (\<forall> i < 3. L ! i \<noteq> 210) \<and>
                 (\<forall> i < 3. (\<Sum> j \<le> i. L ! j) \<noteq> 270) \<and>
                 (\<forall> i < 3. (\<Sum> j \<le> i. L ! j) \<noteq> 300)} /
        card {L. \<exists> S1 S2 S3 S4 S5 S6 S7 S8 S9 S10. 
                 L = [S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, S7, S8, S9, S10] \<and>
                 (\<forall> S. S \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> (S = 30 \<or> S = 60 \<or> S = 90 \<or> S = 120 \<or> S = 150 \<or> S = 180 \<or> S = 210)) \<and>
                 (\<forall> S1 S2. S1 \<noteq> S2 \<longrightarrow> S1 \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> S2 \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> S1 \<noteq> S2)})"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An o-Pod MP3 player stores and plays entire songs. Celeste has 10 songs stored on her o-Pod. The time length of each song is different. When the songs are ordered by length, the shortest song is only 30 seconds long and each subsequent song is 30 seconds longer than the previous song. Her favorite song is 3 minutes, 30 seconds long. The o-Pod will play all the songs in random order before repeating any song. What is the probability that she hears the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds of music - there are no pauses between songs - without hearing every second of her favorite song? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{79}{90}
 ### Proof
 We will calculate the probability of her hearing every second of her favorite song and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $10!$ ways in which the 10 songs can be ordered.
 If her favorite song is the first song, she obviously hears the whole thing, and then there are $9!$ ways to order the other songs. If the first song is the 30 second song, then she will hear the entirety of her favorite song if and only if it is played as the second song, after which there are $8!$ ways to order the other songs.
 Finally, if the first song is the 1 minute song, she will hear her favorite song if and only if it is played as the second song, after which there are $8!$ ways to order the other songs. If the first song is longer than a minute, or if two songs are played before her first song, she won't have time to hear all of her favorite song in the first 4 minutes, 30 seconds.
 So out of the $10!$ ways of ordering the 10 songs, there are $9! + 8! + 8!$ ways that result in her hearing the full song for a probability of $\dfrac{9!+8!+8!}{10!}=\dfrac{8!}{8!}\cdot\dfrac{9+1+1}{10\cdot9}=\dfrac{11}{90}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{11}{90}=\boxed{\dfrac{79}{90}}$
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (79 / 90)"
shows  "p = (card {L. \<exists> S1 S2 S3 S4 S5 S6 S7 S8 S9 S10. 
                 L = [S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, S7, S8, S9, S10] \<and>
                 (\<forall> S. S \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> (S = 30 \<or> S = 60 \<or> S = 90 \<or> S = 120 \<or> S = 150 \<or> S = 180 \<or> S = 210)) \<and>
                 (\<forall> S1 S2. S1 \<noteq> S2 \<longrightarrow> S1 \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> S2 \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> S1 \<noteq> S2) \<and>
                 (\<forall> i < 3. L ! i \<noteq> 210) \<and>
                 (\<forall> i < 3. (\<Sum> j \<le> i. L ! j) \<noteq> 270) \<and>
                 (\<forall> i < 3. (\<Sum> j \<le> i. L ! j) \<noteq> 300)} /
        card {L. \<exists> S1 S2 S3 S4 S5 S6 S7 S8 S9 S10. 
                 L = [S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, S7, S8, S9, S10] \<and>
                 (\<forall> S. S \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> (S = 30 \<or> S = 60 \<or> S = 90 \<or> S = 120 \<or> S = 150 \<or> S = 180 \<or> S = 210)) \<and>
                 (\<forall> S1 S2. S1 \<noteq> S2 \<longrightarrow> S1 \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> S2 \<in> set L \<longrightarrow> S1 \<noteq> S2)})"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A list of ten steps, each being one of the following: 30, 60, 90, 120, 150, 180, or 210, is chosen such that no two steps in the list are the same. Calculate the probability that the first three steps do not include 210, the sum of the first two steps is not 270, and the sum of the first three steps is not 300. The final answer is $\frac{79}{90}$.
